title: Healthcare Data Scientist at Health Tech Companies
text: Healthcare data scientists at companies like Tempus, Flatiron Health, and Color Health combine medical domain knowledge with machine learning to improve patient outcomes. Daily responsibilities: 40% building predictive models for clinical outcomes and treatment recommendations, 30% working with clinical data (EHR, genomics, imaging), 20% collaborating with physicians and clinical researchers, 10% presenting findings to stakeholders. Typical projects include: Developing ML models to predict patient readmission risk. Building NLP pipelines to extract information from clinical notes. Creating risk stratification models for chronic diseases. Analyzing genomic data for precision medicine. Building computer vision models for medical imaging analysis. Required skills: Python (scikit-learn, TensorFlow, PyTorch), SQL for querying clinical databases, R for statistical analysis, understanding of healthcare data standards (HL7, FHIR), knowledge of medical terminology and clinical workflows, experience with EHR systems, strong communication skills to work with non-technical clinicians. Technical stack: Python data science libraries, cloud platforms (AWS, GCP), Spark for big data, Docker for deployment, Git for version control, Jupyter notebooks for exploration. Educational background: MS or PhD in computer science, biostatistics, or biomedical informatics preferred. Many come from CS backgrounds and learn healthcare on the job. Challenges: Dealing with messy, unstructured clinical data. Ensuring model fairness and avoiding bias. Meeting HIPAA compliance and privacy requirements. Validating models with clinical experts. Salary range: $110k-$150k (junior), $150k-$200k (senior), $200k-$280k (principal/staff level). Career path: Data Scientist → Senior Data Scientist → Lead Data Scientist → Director of Data Science or Chief Data Scientist.
author: HealthTech Careers

title: Clinical Informatics Specialist Role
text: Clinical informatics specialists bridge the gap between healthcare and technology, working at hospitals, health systems, and digital health startups. Role breakdown: 35% implementing and optimizing EHR systems (Epic, Cerner), 25% analyzing clinical workflows and data, 20% training clinical staff on new systems, 20% collaborating with IT and clinical departments. Key responsibilities: Configuring EHR systems to support clinical workflows. Analyzing clinical data to identify improvement opportunities. Building clinical decision support tools. Ensuring data quality and interoperability. Managing health IT projects from requirements to deployment. Supporting regulatory compliance (HIPAA, meaningful use). Required qualifications: Clinical background (RN, MD, PharmD) OR health informatics degree, technical skills in databases and data analysis, understanding of clinical workflows, project management experience, strong communication and change management skills. Technical skills: SQL for querying clinical databases, basic Python or R for analysis, understanding of HL7 and FHIR standards, experience with EHR systems (Epic, Cerner), data visualization tools (Tableau, Power BI), knowledge of healthcare analytics platforms. Tools and systems: Epic or Cerner EHR, clinical data warehouses, BI tools, SQL databases, health information exchanges, patient portals. Work environment: Hospitals, health systems, health tech companies, consulting firms. Career progression: Informatics Analyst → Senior Analyst → Informatics Manager → Director of Clinical Informatics → Chief Medical Information Officer (CMIO). Salary: $75k-$100k (analyst), $100k-$140k (senior), $140k-$190k (manager/director). Growing field with high demand as healthcare becomes more data-driven.
author: Clinical Informatics Association

title: Bioinformatics Analyst Responsibilities
text: Bioinformatics analysts at biotech companies, research institutes, and pharma work at the intersection of biology, computer science, and statistics. At companies like Genentech, Illumina, and 23andMe, analysts spend: 45% analyzing genomic and molecular data (DNA sequencing, RNA-seq, proteomics), 30% developing computational pipelines and tools, 15% collaborating with wet-lab scientists, 10% presenting results and writing reports. Common projects: Analyzing next-generation sequencing (NGS) data to identify genetic variants. Building pipelines for RNA-seq analysis to study gene expression. Performing genome-wide association studies (GWAS). Analyzing single-cell sequencing data. Developing tools for protein structure prediction. Creating databases for biological data management. Technical skills required: Programming in Python (BioPython, pandas) and R (Bioconductor), Linux/Unix command line proficiency, experience with bioinformatics tools (BLAST, Samtools, GATK), understanding of statistics and machine learning, knowledge of molecular biology and genetics, SQL for database management, high-performance computing experience. Tools and platforms: R/Bioconductor for statistical analysis, Python for pipeline development, Galaxy for workflow management, UCSC Genome Browser, Ensembl, NCBI databases, cloud computing (AWS, GCP), containerization (Docker, Singularity), version control (Git), workflow managers (Snakemake, Nextflow). Educational requirements: MS or PhD in bioinformatics, computational biology, or related field. Strong candidates have biology background with programming skills OR CS background with biology knowledge. Salary ranges: $85k-$110k (junior analyst), $110k-$150k (senior analyst), $150k-$200k (principal scientist). Career trajectory: Bioinformatics Analyst → Senior Scientist → Principal Scientist → Director of Bioinformatics. Opportunities in academia, biotech, pharma, and health tech.
